page.title: 10Wyre Forest - Economics
page.content: The Forestry Commission planted large areas of Douglas Fir c.1926 which is due to mature 1980-90. Good timber will be produced for{construction} work. Larch, which produces good poles after only 15 years, was also planted but late frosts and dry soil inhibit its growth and it is gradually being replaced by Corsican Pine, which grows well in less fertile areas,and Douglas Fir. The timber is used for{pulp}and {box making.}The only broadleaved tree to be planted is Beech. Started c.1940 it is not yet mature but is in demand for{furniture.}Some older Oaks are growing from coppiced stumps but are only good for{posts}and{stakes}Bark is sent to a{tanner}in St.Ives, Brushwood supplies the{floristry}trade and Larch is sold to the{fencing}industry.A very minor source of income is the sale of {venison}when deer are culled.
